Fig. 2 Turnover number vs. micromoles of Ru per m2 of surface area of support revealing a dependence on the nature of the supports (TiO2, Al2O3, Carbon, and SiO2) and effects related to particle size. Fig. 3 Temperature dependence of the standard (1atm) Gibbs Free Energy of reaction Δ G r ° for the reactions xH2O+phenol→product+ yH2O for the products observed. Production of benzene is favorable at all temperatures, while hydrogenation is favorable only at lower temperatures. Fig. 4 The Direct Deoxygenation (DDO) and Hydrogenation (HYD) pathways, widely observed in the hydrodeoxygenation of phenol. Fig. 5 Particle size dependence of (A) the reaction rate constant for conversion of phenol, k eff (Ru site s)−1; (B) selectivity toward benzene, k DDO eff / k HYD eff ; and (C) the reaction rate constant for production of cyclohexenol from phenol, k HYD eff . Fig. 6 (A) Fractional yield for DDO as a function of the reduction temperature of the catalyst, and (B) TON as a function of particle size. The high selectivity of Ru/TiO2-U (85%) which has a small average particle size (1.5nm) and is relatively easily reduced (453K) suggests that the DDO pathway involves highly dispersed, but easily reduced Ru particles, while the HYD pathway occurs on larger Ru0 particles. Fig. 7 Schematic illustration of how large Ru particles may facilitate hydrogenation (left) while smaller particles on titania could function to dissociate hydrogen and catalyze the reduction of TiO2 to Ti4O7 or other Ti3+ defect sites where the phenol hydroxyl group can form a TiO bond, leading to hydrogenolysis in a DDO mechanism (right). Graphical abstract Substituted phenols are the most recalcitrant oxygenates in conventional pyrolysis oils and the dominant oxygenates in lower-oxygen content, formate-assisted pyrolysis oils (FAsP). Ru catalysts with a wide range of dispersion on carbon, silica, alumina, and titania supports were synthesized, characterized and evaluated for hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) activity using phenol as a model compound. Metal content, phase, and particle size were determined with ICP-OES, EXAFS/XANES, and CO pulse chemisorption, respectively. High dispersion of ruthenium on the supports converts more phenol to products. The majority of catalysts predominantly catalyze the hydrogenation (HYD) route typical of noble metal catalysts. A highly dispersed Ru/TiO2 catalyst shows unusually high selectivity toward direct deoxygenation (DDO) and outstanding activity. We suggest that the DDO pathway on titania involves a bifunctional catalyst, where hydrogen creates reduced titania sites, created by hydrogen spillover, that interact strongly with the phenol hydroxyl group. Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Ru heterogeneous catalyst Formate Assisted pyrolysis oils (FAsP) EXAFS Biofuels TiO2 MCM-41 SBA-15 1 Introduction Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is a class of reactions utilized to upgrade the quality of biofuels, typically involving heating pyrolysis oil to 573–873K under high pressures of hydrogen over a heterogeneous catalyst [1–12]. Early HDO attempts used catalysts and reactor conditions from hydrodesulfurization and hydrodenitrogenation processes developed for the treatment of petroleum feeds [9,13] to limit SOx and NOx emissions [14]. Recent HDO experiments have incorporated a wide variety of active metals (Ru [2,15], Pd [16–18], Mo [2], Pt [15,16]), metal phosphides [19–21] and catalyst frameworks, (active carbon [2,15,17] mesoporous silicas [18,22,23], zeolite [17] and alumina [15]). These recent approaches are preferable to traditional hydrotreatment catalysts (sulfided NiMo/Al2O3 and CoMo/Al2O3) because they do not introduce sulfur into the manufacturing process with the concomitant risk of contaminating a naturally sulfur-free fuel [15]. Recent advances have been reviewed, and while model compound studies have identified reaction networks, a fundamental understanding of reaction mechanisms, kinetics, and the nature of the active sites is still lacking [24]. Recently, our group has developed a new pyrolysis process called formate-assisted pyrolysis (FAsP) involving co-feeding of biomass and formate salts [25–28] that results in oxygen contents of about 8%, compared to 40–45% in conventional bio-oils [29–33]. Chemical analysis shows that while the oxygen content is greatly improved, the FAsP oils remain rich in substituted phenols [27,28]. Thus, for FAsP oils specifically, and bio-oils more generally, the ability to upgrade phenolic compounds is critical. Substituted phenols like guaiacol [34–40] are readily converted to phenol or catechol under traditional upgrading processes, but the catalytic conversion of phenol to an oxygen-free compound is difficult [41,42] as the CO bond in phenol is among the more difficult bonds to cleave in bio-oils [24,43–45]. Phenol also provides a useful probe of the catalytic reaction mechanisms, specifically providing insight into whether hydrogen used in the reaction is being directed towards hydrogenation or direct deoxygenation. In this report, we present data on a series of supported Ru catalysts designed for the hydrodeoxygenation of fast pyrolysis oils. We correlate variations in activity and selectivity for reactions of phenol with physical properties of the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37%), ruthenium (III) chloride hydrate (RuCl3·XH2O), tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, 99.999%), carbon nanofibers (CNF, iron free, graphitized, conical, >99%), Ru on carbon (Ru/C, 5wt%) and Ru on alumina (Ru/Al2O3, 5% Ru basis) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. A 5% Ru on carbon was also obtained from Strem. Poly(ethylene oxide)–poly(propylene oxide)–poly(ethylene oxide) (Mr =5750, EO20PO70EO20, Pluronic P123) was obtained from BASF. Liquified phenol (>89%, ∼10% H2O) was obtained from Fischer Scientific. Silica gel granules (SG, silica gel no. 646, 35–60 mesh) were obtained from W.R. Grace & Co. MCM-41 was received as a generous gift from Martin Piech when he was in the Yale University Department of Chemical Engineering. SG, MCM-41 and CNF supports were impregnated as received. Titanium dioxide P25 was purchased from Degussa. NORIT activated carbon support was used for the synthesized Ru/C catalyst. Aluminum oxide support was purchased from Acros Organics. Reference standards for X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements, Ru powder (Mesh 22), RuCl3·xH2O, RuO2, and RuO2·xH2O were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. All materials in this work were used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis and impregnation SBA-15 was synthesized following a modified literature procedure, as described previously [46]. Two different metal impregnation approaches were used. All catalyst supports were oven dried prior to impregnation. For porous silica supports, MCM-41, SBA-15 and silica gel (SG), incipient wetness impregnation [47–50], [51] (IWI) was used following a modified IWI literature procedure [51]. A solution of RuCl3·XH2O, calculated to theoretical metal loadings ranging from 0.5 to 10wt%, was prepared in a total pore volume (TPV) equivalent of H2O. The solution was added dropwise to each support and left to age overnight. Samples were then dried in air overnight at 353K. Those used at this stage were designated as (U) for uncalcined. Selected catalysts were calcined in air at 873K for 8h using a ramp rate of 1K/min and designated as (C) for calcined. For low porosity CNF, TiO2, Al2O3, and C supports, wetness impregnation (WI) was employed following a modified literature procedure [47]. A solution of RuCl3·XH2O (35mL) was prepared to attempt to achieve a final metal loading near 5wt%. The solution was added dropwise to the support and aged overnight. The catalyst was then dried at 383K for 20h. Selected catalysts were calcined in air at 473K for 4h using a ramp rate of 1K/min. In summary, the following catalysts were either purchased or synthesized and studied in this report: Carbon-based supports: Ru/C from Strem, Ru/C from Acros, Ru/C-U (synthesized uncalcined), Ru/CNF; Silica-based supports: Ru/SBA-15, Ru-SG, Ru/MCM-41 (low metal content), Ru/MCM-41 (medium metal content), Ru/MCM-41 (high metal content), Ru/MCM-41-U (uncalcined) Alumina-based supports: Ru/Al2O3 (SA) (purchased from sigma aldrich), Ru/Al2O3-U (synthesized uncalcined); Titania-based supports: Ru/TiO2, Ru/TiO2–U (uncalcined). All synthesized catalysts were calcined unless specified. 2.3 Catalyst characterization 2.3.1 N2 porosimetry Nitrogen sorption isotherms were determined at 77K using a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 instrument. Surface area, total pore volume and pore size calculations were performed using standard approaches. Surface area was calculated from the BET plot [52], total pore volume (TPV) was obtained from the single point adsorption volume at P/P 0 =0.995, and the average pore size reported is the average adsorption branch BJH [53] pore diameter (4V/A), using the KJS [54] correction. 2.3.2 Metal determination Ru content analysis was performed by Galbraith Laboratories or done using a Thermo Scientific iCAP 600 ICP-OES spectrometer with microwave-assisted digestion. 2.3.3 X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy For the characterization of the local electronic and atomic structure of Ru in the catalysts, we performed synchrotron based X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements at the bend magnet beamline X18B at the National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory. The as prepared (calcined or uncalcined) powder catalyst samples were pressed into solid pellets (∼150mg in pellets of ∼10mm dia, pressure 6 tons) and loaded into a Nashner-Adler reactor for in situ transmission studies. Catalysts were reduced using 5% H2/He flow while heating at a ramp rate of 20K/min to 673K. Reduction occurred during the first 15min of the temperature ramp, between 500 and 650K. The catalysts were held at the final temperature for 4h, although no further changes were observed. Passivation was performed at room temperature under 5% O2/He flow. The reduction and passivation processes were monitored in situ during the temperature ramp using X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectroscopy, while the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) was measured for each sample at the completion of the chemical reaction (i.e. at steady state). Three ion gas chambers were used to record in transmission mode, the incident (filled with Ar/He), transmitted (filled with Ar/Kr), and reference (filled with Ar/He) beam. A Ru foil was placed after the second ion chamber as both an energy calibration (Ru K-edge: 22.1keV) as well as a reference XANES/EXAFS spectrum for direct comparison to the catalytic samples. Four scans were taken and subsequently averaged during data processing. Reference spectra were measured for Ru, RuCl3·xH2O, RuO2, and RuO2·xH2O and are provided in the supplemental material. 2.3.4 EXAFS analysis Data processing and analysis was done using the Horae [55] suite of IFEFFIT programs [56]. Initial estimates of the threshold energy values (E 0) were obtained via the inflection point in the normalized absorption edges. A Hanning window was applied to a selected k-range (nominally 3Å−1 < k <14Å−1) to obtain high quality Fourier transformed EXAFS data. Fitting of the Ru foil standard led to a passive electron reduction factor ( S o 2 ) of 0.77, where this value was fixed for the analysis of the catalyst samples. Using a Ru bulk metal (hcp) chemical model, FEFF6 was used [57] to calculate the photoelectron scattering path amplitudes, F i (k), and phase, φ i (k), and the samples were fit to the EXAFS equation, (1) χ i ( k ) = N i S o 2 2 k R i 2 F i ( k ) e − 2 k 2 σ i 2 sin ⁡ [ 2 k R i + ϕ i ( k ) ] , which allowed for the extraction of pertinent information including the coordination numbers (N i ), bond lengths (R i ), and the EXAFS Debye-Waller factors (static disorders, σ i 2 ). 2.3.5 Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) and CO adsorption Reducibility and dispersion measurements were made using H2 TPR and CO chemisorption with a catalyst characterization system (AMI-200RHP, Altamira Instrument Inc.). The product stream from the TCD could also be sampled via a capillary into a mass spectrometer (SRS RGA-100). For all carbon supported catalysts except Ru/CNF, the catalysts were very fine powders and mass loss during CO chemisorption made particle size determination unreliable. For catalysts that were calcined during synthesis, the catalyst sample was calcined in air at 673K, held for 1h, flushed in Ar for 30min, and cooled to room temperature. For catalysts that were not calcined during synthesis, the TPR/CO adsorption measurements were performed both with and without calcination. Catalysts were reduced prior to CO chemisorption by heating at 10K/min to 723K and holding for 1h, in a 10% H2 +90% Ar gas flow, and then cooled in Ar to 303K. The dispersion on the freshly reduced catalysts was estimated using CO pulse chemisorption measurements with a 10% CO+90% He gas mixture at 303K. 2.4 Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation and hydrogenation of phenol 2.4.1 Reaction conditions All catalysts were reduced to activate the catalysts for 4h at 673K using a 3:1N2:H2 gas mixture prior to reaction. The total flow rate was adjusted to 150mL/min and a heating ramp rate of 20K/min was used. Following reduction, samples were weighed and submerged in phenol within 10min of removal from the reduction chamber to minimize air exposure. Reactions were conducted using a 25mL batch reactor (Parr, Model 4596). 15mL of liquefied phenol and 0.1g of reduced catalyst were first added to the reactor. The vessel was then sealed and flushed with nitrogen. Following an increase in nitrogen pressure to 50psi (added to allow consistent temperature readings at the target temperature), the vessel was heated to 573K. Hydrogen was then introduced to provide a total reactor pressure of 650psi. The reaction continued for 1h with stirring at 500rpm. Hydrogen was reintroduced throughout the reaction to maintain a 650psi total reactor pressure. At no point in the reaction did the amount of N2 exceed 20%. 2.4.2 Gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GC-MS) Samples were analyzed using an Agilent 689N Network GC System with a 6890 Series Injector and 5973N Network Mass Selective Detector with a HP-5MS crosslinked 5% PH ME Siloxane capillary column (dimensions of 30m×0.25mm×0.25μm). The method was 6min at 308K, a ramp at 5K/min to 398K and held for 10min, then a final ramp at 30K/min to 573K, and held for 10min. Two μL of reaction product was added to 1mL of hexadecanes. The samples were injected without a solvent delay and the mass selective detector turned off after all compounds of interest had eluted. 3 Results 3.1 Materials characterization 3.1.1 Surface area and loading Surface area, total pore volume, average pore size and % Ru were determined for all catalysts, whether synthesized or purchased, as summarized in Table 1 . For most catalyst types, duplicate synthesis and/or multiple catalytic reactions were carried out and averages of the data are reported. 3.1.2 CO chemisorption to measure particle size and % dispersion Dispersion and particle size were determined from the uptake of CO measured by CO pulse chemisorption at 303K and are reported in Table 1. The dispersion, D= RuS/Ru0, where the number of surface Ru sites per gram catalyst, RuS, was taken to be equal to the moles of CO adsorbed per gram. The amount of Ru metal per gram catalyst, Ru0, was calculated from the total Ru loading measured by ICP-OES times the fraction of Ru0 determined from XAS analysis, if available. For other calcined catalysts, the fraction of reduced Ru atoms was calculated from TPR data assuming that the initial phase was RuO2. In those cases where the amount of hydrogen consumed exceeded 100% of the Ru present, the assumption was made that the catalyst was fully reduced. The average particle diameter, d, was calculated from D assuming hemispherical particles, a density ρ Ru =12.45g/cm3 and an areal surface atom density, σ =1.58×1015 atoms/cm2, according to d =2A W σ/ρ Ru N A D, where A W is the atomic weight and N A is Avogadro's number. We note that for all but a few catalysts of low dispersion, no X-ray diffraction lines associated with any phase of Ru could be detected. Although reduction temperature often decreased for larger particles, effects of support identity, morphology, and catalyst pretreatment (calcination vs. direct reduction) obscured any clear dependence on particle size. 3.1.3 Speciation of metal on catalyst from EXAFS Catalysts were analyzed by EXAFS to determine the phase composition before and after reduction, and with XANES during reduction under conditions used for TPR measurements and during catalyst activation. Representative data are illustrated for Ru/MCM-41-U (Fig. 1 ) and Ru/SG and Ru/Al2O3 (SA) (supporting material) and phase characterization is given in Table 2 . In part A of each figure, we illustrate the time dependence of the XANES spectra while heating at 20K/min under reducing conditions (irrespective of support). For all the calcined samples, rapid reduction of some portion of the Ru(IV) to Ru metal occurred, with reduction complete by about 520K (Al2O3), 600K (MCM-41, CNF), and 650K (TiO2). In part B of these figures, we compare the EXAFS interference functions before and after reduction with that of the Ru foil standard. Part B also compares the Fourier transformed EXAFS data with the theoretical fit. Fitting was performed out to 4Å in R space and from 2Å−1 to 14Å−1 in k space using a combination of bulk Ru, RuCl3, RuO2·xH2O, and/or RuO2 models, as appropriate. The fractional contribution of each of these models was allowed to vary during the fitting procedure. As illustrated in Fig. 1, this model fit the data well over the fitting range. EXAFS data on the calcined and reduced silica supported materials was essentially identical to Ru foil (hcp crystal structure). The similarity indicates that the Ru particles had bonding environments similar to that of bulk metal [58]. For Ru/SBA-15 and Ru/SG after calcination the Ru was essentially completely oxidized to RuO2, and after reduction was 91% reduced. The interference functions (Part B) and coordination shells (PartC) were very similar for the SBA-15- and SG-supported catalysts after reduction. For Ru/Al2O3(SA), the spectrum of the as-prepared catalyst was a mixture of RuO2 and hydrous RuO2, but after reduction only 87% of the Ru was reduced. For the carbon supports, reduction varied from 84 to 93% for calcined catalysts. There are significant differences between the interference functions and coordination shells after reduction vs. the Ru foil reference standard when the Ru was not fully reduced. For catalysts that were impregnated with RuCl3 and not calcined, the XANES data were fit to a linear combination of RuCl3, RuO2·H2O, and Ru. In addition to differences in the shape of the absorption edge for RuCl3 compared to that of RuO2, the absolute photon energy corresponding to the edge varied linearly with formal oxidation state (shown in the supplementary material for the standards). For Ru/MCM-41-U, the as-prepared composition is a mixture of Ru3+ and Ru4+. After reduction, 89.1% of the catalyst is reduced. The extent of reduction for the Ru/TiO2-U catalyst was 92.4%, but for the Ru/C-U catalyst only 51.8% reduction was achieved. In all cases, the amount of RuCl3 is small post-reduction, in no case greater than 12% and in many cases it was 0. EXAFS or XANES results were used to estimate the percentage of total metal (determined from ICP) that was reduced for use in dispersion calculations from CO Pulse Chemisorption as described above. 3.2 Catalytic results The selectivity of the catalysts with respect to the hydrodeoxygenation of phenol with H2 at 573K is summarized in Table 3 . The product distribution is given as a mole percentage of all phenol-derived products for each catalyst as well as the percent of the total products that are deoxygenated (benzene, cyclohexane, and cyclohexene). The data is averaged from 2 to 4 analyses of products from duplicate reactions and/or duplicate catalyst syntheses. Yields of each were quantified from calibrated GC-MS spectra. The percent conversion varied between 2% and 20%. However, we draw attention to the results for Ru/MCM-41-U, Ru/C-U, Ru/Al2O3(SA), and Ru/TiO2-U, which all had approximately 10% conversion, but showed dramatically different selectivities, clearly showing differences in the reaction pathway on the four supports. The Ru/Al2O3(SA) catalyst showed the smallest percentage of deoxygenated products (4.9%) while the Ru/TiO2-U catalyst gave the highest percentage of deoxygenated products (86%), essentially completely benzene. Turnover number, which is calculated as total number of moles of phenol transformed per mole of ruthenium over the course of the reaction is presented in Table 3. This measure makes no assumptions about the active phase of the catalyst or particle size. The TON varies by nearly two orders of magnitude. Fig. 2 presents the turnover number vs. total micromoles of Ru per m2 of surface area. The data reveals clear distinctions between the four supports as well as a general increase in reactivity as the areal density of ruthenium decreases, suggesting that increases in dispersion lead to greater Ru atom efficiency. Catalysts that were reduced directly after impregnation, without an initial calcination step, showed higher activity. Calcined Ru/MCM-41 has a TON of 120molphenolconverted/molRu while the uncalcined analog has a TON of 430. Calcined Ru/TiO2 has a TON of 160molphenolconverted/molRu while the uncalcined analog has a TON of 1640molphenolconverted/molRu. 4 Discussion The goal of this work is to develop effective materials to catalyze the hydrodeoxygenation of phenolic compounds that are found in many wood-based bio oils. Traditional hydrodesulfurization catalysts are effective and make efficient use of hydrogen in upgrading bio-oils, producing aromatic hydrocarbons through direct deoxygenation (DDO), but they rapidly lose activity unless a sulfur source is fed, which leads to sulfur contamination of the bio-oil [24]. Recent model compound studies have focused on noble metal catalysts, which show better yields but utilize the hydrogenation (HYD) pathway which consumes considerably more hydrogen [24,59–65]. In the HYD pathway, phenol is first reduced to cyclohexanol and then dehydrated to form cyclohexane, which has the advantage that hydrogenation and dehydration can be accomplished at lower temperatures [66,67]. The desirability of each reaction pathway is therefore determined by the relative cost of hydrogen and the characteristics required of the end product. There are pronounced differences in the selectivity of the Ru catalysts we have synthesized in terms of their proclivity to use the HYD and DDO pathways. Understanding the factors that control this selectivity will enable the design of catalysts for particular products and is therefore a prime interest. 4.1 Catalytic reaction mechanism Hydrogenation of phenol can yield many products. Fig. 3 shows the temperature dependence of the standard state Gibbs Free Energy of reaction, Δ G rxn ° , for the products observed, according to the stoichiometric reaction, xH2 +phenol→product+ yH2O, where the number of moles of H2, x, and H2O, y, varies for each of the products. Hydrogenation is thermodynamically favorable at lower temperatures but the decrease in number of gas phase molecules causes ΔS rxn to be negative and Δ G rxn ° to become unfavorable at higher temperatures. By contrast, the Δ G rxn ° for deoxygenation of phenol to benzene is essentially independent of temperature and therefore becomes the thermodynamically favored reaction above 550K. Reports indicate that the reaction of phenol at pressures above 10bar and temperatures above 473K and favors deoxygenation [43,67,68]. The products reported from reactions of phenol [42,67,69–74] and substituted phenols [3,39,41,75–81] suggest two deoxygenation routes: hydrogenation (HYD) followed by dehydration; and direct deoxygenation (DDO) [77], also referred to as hydrogenolysis. The DDO and HYD reaction scheme is displayed in Fig. 4 . Evidence for these two pathways, first suggested by Moldavskii and Livishits [79], is found not only in work with molybdenum sulfide-based catalysts [39,41,69,75–78,81,82], where the reaction scheme is analogous to the hydrodesulfurization of benzothiophenes [83,84], but also with metal catalysts [38,42,67,70,71,80]. The HYD pathway proceeds first through the partial hydrogenation of the aromatic ring, which produces cyclohexenol, an unstable product that rapidly tautomerizes to form cyclohexanone [70,71]. Cyclohexanone and substituted analogs are then converted to the corresponding cyclohexanol through the catalytic addition of H2 [67,70,71]. Cyclohexanol is then dehydrated to form cyclohexene and water [38,39,41,42,67,72,75]. A final hydrogenation step converts the cyclohexenes to cyclohexanes [38,39,41,42,67,71,75,76]. Under standard pressure at 573K, formation of cyclohexanone and reduction to cyclohexanol are both thermodynamically unfavorable (Fig. 3), but the subsequent steps in the HYD pathway are favorable, with the cyclohexane product being comparable in energy to benzene. The large amount of cyclohexanone observed for most catalysts suggests that the barrier to hydrogenation of the ketone controls the rate of the HYD pathway (see Table 3). Differences in the relative amounts of cyclohexanol and cyclohexene indicate that the barrier to dehydration of cyclohexanol varies within the set of catalysts. Qualitatively, the relative concentrations we observe are consistent with the quantitative measurements of the rate constants in the HYD pathway of phenol on Pd/C by Zhao, et al. [85] The DDO pathway instead proceeds through the direct hydrogenolysis of the alcohol to produce benzene, which is the most stable product at 573K. Incomplete hydrogenation of benzene to form cyclohexene is unlikely as the reaction is thermodynamically unfavorable [67]. Clear evidence for the parallel mechanisms of Fig. 4 was given by Gevert et al. [69], who showed that the mole fraction of toluene, produced from the DDO of 4-methylphenol over CoMo catalysts at 573K and 5MPa, was proportional to conversion. Romero et al. [77] report that HYD and DDO pathways for the hydrodeoxygenation of 2-ethylphenol over a MoS2 catalyst occur in parallel so that ethylcyclohexane was produced exclusively through HYD. This assertion was supported with experiments showing that, under their reaction conditions (613K, 7MPa), hydrogenation of ethylbenzene to ethylcyclohexane did not occur. The parallel route hypothesis is also supported by a study conducted over NiO-MoO3 and NiO-WO3 catalysts at 613K and 7MPa that shows the rate of benzene hydrogenation is 20 times less than the rate of phenol hydrogenation to cyclohexane [77,86]. 4.2 Catalyst selectivity and active phase of Ru Based upon the mechanism of Fig. 4, we take the rates of the DDO and HYD reactions for conversion of phenol to be given by, (2) r DDO = k DDO C phenol p H 2 x s Ru (3) r HYD = k HYD C phenol p H 2 y s Ru where the order in the concentration of phenol, C phenol, and in Ru surface sites per gram catalyst, s Ru, is first order, but the orders in hydrogen pressure, p H 2 , are not specified. The moles of Ru surface sites per gram catalyst is given by: s Ru = m Ru D/m cat A W , where m Ru and m cat are the mass of Ru and catalyst, respectively. If p H 2 and s Ru are constant for a given reaction, then the rates are pseudo-first order in phenol, with k DDO eff = k DDO p H 2 x s Ru and k HYD eff = k HYD p H 2 x s Ru . For a branching mechanism, the total rate of phenol conversion is, (4) r phenol = ( k DDO eff + k HYD eff ) C phenol = k eff C phenol The conversion of phenol, X = ( C phenol 0 − C phenol ) / C phenol 0 , varied significantly among the catalysts. To account for this, the solution to the design equation for a well stirred batch reactor, C phenol 0 ( d X / d t ) = − k eff C phenol V , is k eff =−ln (1− X)/t, where we take t =1h and k eff = k DDo eff + k HYD eff . If benzene is produced solely via the DDO pathway, then k DDO =−ln (1− X)Y benz/t, where Y benz is the fractional yield of benzene. The rate constant for the first step in the HYD pathway can then be found by difference, k HYD eff = k eff − k DDO eff , and the selectivity for DDO is S DDO = k DDo eff / k HYD eff . Fig. 5 A shows k eff as a function of particle size. k eff is the sum of the pseudo first order rate constants and is shown normalized to the moles of surface Ru sites. Note the logarithmic particle size scale. The values of k eff (mol Ru sites)−1 s−1 vary from 0.9 to 80(mol Ru sites)−1 s−1, corresponding to an average turnover frequency of 0.14 to 20 molecules reacting per surface Ru site per second. There is no clear dependence on the support. In Fig. 5B, we show the selectivity for production of benzene as a function of particle size. There is no clear particle size or support dependence for catalysts with low selectivity toward benzene (0.03–0.3), but for the highly dispersed Ru/TiO2(U) catalysts the selectivity is 5.5, and the high dispersion results in the highest overall TON for phenol of 1640 (Table 3). Because of difficulties determining the particle size for many of the carbon catalysts, the data for carbon supports is limited to the carbon nanofibers where particle size determinations were made. Fig. 5C shows the effective rate constant, k HYD eff , for the first step in the HYD pathway as a function of particle size, but again no significant differences between supports. Thus, this analysis shows that the increase in TON with decreasing metal areal density is dominated by an increase in dispersion (see Fig. 2). To gain some insight into whether the active phase is reduced Ru metal, an oxide, such as RuO2, or a core shell structure with RuO x /Ru [87–89], we show the fractional yield of the DDO product, benzene, Y benz, as a function of reduction temperature, and the TON as a function of particle size, in Figs. 6 A and B, respectively. The Ru/TiO2-U catalyst, which is highly active and selective toward benzene (85%), has a relatively low reduction temperature (453K), especially considering its small particle size (1.5nm). (Note, that the selectivity for DDO and HYD are complementary, so we show only the %DDO as a function of reduction temperature in Fig. 6.) The general trend is that, as the reduction temperature decreases, selectivity toward DDO increases, which suggests that the active phase for DDO is a reduced Ru(0) particle or a Ru(0) core with a more easily reduced oxide layer. 4.3 Support effects The most dramatic observation of an effect of support on the overall reactivity is the effect that was seen with TiO2 when it was used to support uncalcined ruthenium. The selectivity of this catalyst is much higher than the selectivity seen with all other supports (Fig. 6A). DDO selectivity is on alumina is significantly lower than on the other supports. The role of TiO2 might be explained by a “spillover mechanism”, in which small Ru particles could facilitate hydrogen dissociation and the hydrogen in turn could diffuse to the support where Ti4+ is reduced to Ti3+ Lewis acid sites. The metal oxide bond strength in TiO2, 660kJ/mol [90], is very large, and the possibility of cleaving the phenol COH bond via a DDO mechanism appears much more plausible than via RuO bond formation, since the RuO bond strength of 123kJ/mol for Ru2O3 [91] and 157 to 281kJ/mol for RuO2 [91,92], which is considerably less than the 414kJ/mol estimate of the COH bond in phenol [45]. Clear evidence for the formation of Ti3+ sites under comparable conditions was given by Huizinga and Prins [93] using ESR. Reduction of Pt/TiO2 in H2 at temperatures as low as 573K produce Ti3+ sites that were attributed to formation of Ti4O7 phase in the neighborhood of the metal particles. Several studies [94,95] have attributed the higher activity for CO bond cleavage via a hydrogenolysis process to interaction of the carbonyl oxygen with a reduced Ti3+ site that weakens the CO bond and promotes hydrogenation (or hydrogenolysis). Alternatively, while we think it less likely, a strong metal–support interaction (SMSI) might be responsible for the unique chemistry seen with TiO2 [96,97]. In the SMSI process, a thin TiO x layer covers the transition metal stabilizing reduced Ti3+ sites in the thin oxide overlayer [96,98,99]. This typically results in the rate of C–C hydrogenolysis reactions being reduced by several orders of magnitude, while increasing the rate of CO methanation [100–102]. The high CO/Ru ratios measured in our pulse chemisorption experiments (0.38) compared to that of Tauster et al. [97], and the presence of water, which is known to oxidize the TiO x overlayer and reverse the SMSI state [100], suggest that an SMSI state is not probable. The low selectivity seen with alumina as a support could be associated with the formation of phenolates on the strongly Brønsted acidic support [103]. Chemisorbed phenolates are stabilized, potentially accounting for lower reaction rates on alumina relative to carbon and silica supported catalysts, and facilitating hydrogenation. Carbon supports are generally considered to be neutral and silica has only weak Brønsted acidity; thus, phenolates would not be expected to form on them. For the HYD pathway, the dominant effect on TON (Fig. 2) derives from differences in the ability of the supports to stabilize small particles. At a practical level, higher specific surface area supports will stabilize higher dispersion. Ultimately our working hypothesis is that large Ru particles on any support interact with the aromatic ring and facilitate hydrogenation while on the TiO2 surface, small metal particles [95] create a bifunctional catalyst with the phenyl ring interacting with the metal particle, while the oxygen adsorbs at a reduced Ti3+ site, much as we have modeled for allyl alcohol on MoO3 and WO3 clusters [104,105]. This hypothesis is illustrated in Fig. 7 and will be the subject of future studies. Whether a metal oxide layer with oxygen vacancies partially covers Ru(0) particles and facilitates DDO on other supports remains an open area of investigation as well. 5 Conclusion We have synthesized and characterized a series of supported Ru catalysts and investigated their selectivity for hydrodeoxygenation of phenol. The reactivity data is consistent with a parallel mechanism, involving direct deoxygenation (DDO) to benzene or hydrogenation (HYD) of phenol to cyclohexenol, followed by tautomerization to cyclohexanone, hydration to cyclohexanol, dehydration to cyclohexene, and hydrogenation to cyclohexane. The HYD pathway dominates for the majority of the catalysts. There are no apparent support, pore size or morphology effects for the HYD pathway. For the DDO pathway, the selectivity varies with support, and the overall activity and selectivity is most dramatic for highly dispersed Ru/TiO2. We attribute the effects to a spillover process, in which Ti3+ sites are created and interact strongly with the oxygen, weakening the aromatic CO bond and assisting hydrogenolysis. coredata.dc:description: Substituted phenols are the most recalcitrant oxygenates in conventional pyrolysis oils and the dominant oxygenates in lower-oxygen content, formate-assisted pyrolysis oils (FAsP). Ru catalysts with a wide range of dispersion on carbon, silica, alumina, and titania supports were synthesized, characterized and evaluated for hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) activity using phenol as a model compound. Metal content, phase, and particle size were determined with ICP-OES, EXAFS/XANES, and CO pulse chemisorption, respectively. High dispersion of ruthenium on the supports converts more phenol to products. The majority of catalysts predominantly catalyze the hydrogenation (HYD) route typical of noble metal catalysts. A highly dispersed Ru/TiO2 catalyst shows unusually high selectivity toward direct deoxygenation (DDO) and outstanding activity. We suggest that the DDO pathway on titania involves a bifunctional catalyst, where hydrogen creates reduced titania sites, created by hydrogen spillover, that interact strongly with the phenol hydroxyl group.

coredata.dc:title: Effects of support identity and metal dispersion in supported ruthenium hydrodeoxygenation catalysts
